Service Entry Sheet:- To procure the service from external that is the maintenance has to be done for a machine and there is no team that is present in the plant(internal team) then we will just raise purchase requestion from the maintenance order and after it the material management people will procure the service through ML81N."
Split valuation:- Split valuation for a material has to be configured so that we can perform the refurbishment order.
Details of plant:- The details of plant related namely Purchase Organization, Vendor, Supplier, Outline agreement number etc..
Serial Number Profile:- A serial number profile must be configured for the material to enable the creation of equipment for that material.
Goods Issue:- Goods issue needs to be done for the order otherwise the technician cannot perform the maintenance activities that are present in the order.
Goods Receipt:- Goods receipt has to be done for the Internal Refurbishment Order and the settlement will be done for the material.
Material Reservation:- after creating the maintenance order the materials will be reserved in the inventory automatically.
Procurement:- Procuring of non-stock material, service entry sheet through purchase requestion.

Quality Management:- 
CatLog Profile:- Catlog profile will be configured by the quality management team and it will be assigned for the equipment , functional location.
Calibration Order:- In calibration order inspection will be done and thereby the equipment can be used or not will be determined by the quality management team.

SD(Sales And Distribution):- 
The place where the sales and distribution as well as plant maintenance will gets integrated is in customer service module.

EHS(Environment Health & Safety):-
The integration part of PM with EHS comes only at the product safety, Work permit - while performing any maintenance at the dangerous or hazardous material or equipment's.

FREM(Flexible Real Estate Management):- 
Flexible real estate management and plant maintenance both comes under Enterprise Asset Management in SAP S/4 Hana.
Real Estate Object: - Real estate object will be considered as functional location/equipment.
Work order:- Notification and work order management à maintenance requests originating from RE-FX can be turned into PM notifications/ orders but this will be done with the help of CRM.
Service Provider Coordination: - PM order can trigger external services with the help of MM (material management) to work on RE-FX managed asset.

HCM(Human Capital Management):-
Person Responsible:- Here the person can be assigned to the work order , work center, Technical Object, Operations in work order too.

DMS(Document Management System):-
Documents can be uploaded for the technical objects, notifications , work orders etc... for information or to follow the rules to keep the equipment runs smoothly.

The above are some of the modules for which the plant maintenance will integrate with.

Hope its informative and feel free to comment for any improvements or suggestions.

Regards,
Neeraj.

entry.title: Customer Invoice to Sales Order Reversal Process with Minimal Customizations
entry.content:
Backend System – SAP S/4HANA 2020FP02

 

Business Scenario

There was a scenario where the business generated a large number of incorrect invoices due to faulty automation in the process from sales orders to invoicing. As a result, it became necessary to perform bulk operations to cancel the invoices, reverse the PGIs, delete the deliveries, and reject the associated sales orders. To address this unique situation, a solution was provided with minimal customization.

 

  • Bulk Invoice Cancelation

A LSMW was provided to handle the cancellation of the identified invoices. The relevant user was able to upload the necessary invoice data and perform bulk cancellations efficiently.

 

  • PGI Reversal

As a solution for the PGI reversal, a custom upload program was developed using the standard BAPI WS_REVERSE_GOODS_ISSUE. Users could upload an Excel file in the required format and execute the program to reverse the PGIs in bulk. The program also included a test run option to help identify any potential issues with the deliveries before performing the actual reversal.

The main reason for developing this custom solution was a specific business requirement: the ability to reverse PGIs based on the posting date, which is not feasible in standard transaction VL09 for bulk processing.

While VL09 allows individual PGI reversals and provides the option to change the reversal date, it does not support bulk processing. Hence, a custom solution was necessary to meet the business requirement for reversing multiple PGIs at once with the ability to specify a reversal date.

 

  • Delevery Deletion and Sales Order Rejection

Delivery deletion and sales order rejection can be performed simultaneously using transaction code VKM4. Deliveries that have already been reversed can be deleted through this transaction. On the selection screen, the delivery numbers should be entered in the 'SD Document' field, and the 'Deliveries' checkbox must be selected to ensure proper filtering and execution.

 

The user can then execute transaction VKM4. On the next screen, the 'Processing Status' checkbox should be selected, and the user should choose the 'Reject' option to proceed with the delivery deletion and sales order rejection.

 

The user has the option to decide whether to perform both delivery deletion and sales order rejection simultaneously, or to carry out only the delivery deletion. Based on the requirement, if both actions are needed, the user must select a rejection reason from the search help, click the 'Copy' button, and then click 'Save' to complete the process. In this case, the entire sales order will be rejected using the rejection reason specified in VKM4.

 

 

On the other hand, if the user's requirement is to delete only the delivery without rejecting the sales order, the 'Reason for Rejection' field should be left empty and no value should be selected from the search help. As with the previous case, the user should then click the 'Copy' button followed by the 'Save' button to complete the delivery deletion process.

 

Special thanks to the @Chathuranga_Rajapaksha

entry.title: Use of Settlement Material in SAP S/4HANA Condition Contract
entry.content:
Overview

Entering a settlement material in a condition contract is optional. However, in scenarios such as those involving product groups, where multiple materials are assigned to a specific product group, it is more efficient to perform settlement using a “settlement material” rather than settling each individual material. In such cases, specifying a settlement material in the condition contract becomes necessary.

Key Process Consideration

The material will always be transferred from source document to settlement document if you are using a profile of business volume with a split criteria MATNR (material number). When creating a condition contract, you can enter a settlement material that represents a group of products. Then, when you run the final settlement, system uses this single reference instead of listing every product.

If you want system to use the settlement material instead of the actual product from the original document, you must do following additional settings:

# In split criteria for settlement of profile for BV determination change usage control to “1: Is used – Unless Deactivated via process variant”

 

# Create a new process variant & define a field MATNR in the split criteria and select “1: Do not use as a split criterion” in usage as split criteria”.

Then, create the condition contract and enter the settlement material. define which product group it applies to in business volume selection criteria. Then run the settlement using transactions like WB2R_SC or WB2R_SV. The system will show the settlement material in the final document.

To get the best results make sure your product groups are well set up. Test your setup in a sandbox system to avoid issues. Use clear names for settlement materials so reports are easy to understand. Also, make sure your setup matches how your business tracks volumes and sales.

Using settlement material also helps simplify accounting because you don’t need a separate rule for each product. It makes reporting easier since you can track performance using one reference. You can even automate the selection of settlement materials to save time. And if business handles thousands of products, this feature can really speed things up.

Conclusion

Settlement material is a powerful tool in SAP S/4HANA that can make contract and settlement management much easier. It helps you work faster, stay organized & get clearer insights. With the right setup and testing  it can be a big help for both customer and vendor settlements.

Happy Learning!

entry.title: How to create a new ship-to address and assign it to delivery on creation using exit in ECC?
entry.content:
User exit: MV50AFZ1

Routine: userexit_save_document_prepare

DATA: ls_adrc TYPE addr1_data,
ls_adrc_new TYPE addr1_data,
l_h32 TYPE guid_32,
l_handle TYPE szad_field-handle,
l_ag TYPE adrc-addr_group,
l_ret TYPE szad_field-returncode,
l_ref TYPE addr_ref,
l_nadrnr TYPE adrc-addrnumber,
lt_errtab TYPE TABLE OF addr_error WITH DEFAULT KEY.

LOOP AT xvbpa ASSIGNING FIELD-SYMBOL(<fs_vbpa>) WHERE parvw = 'WE'. " Ship-To
"Read current address
SELECT SINGLE * FROM adrc INTO @DATA(wa_adrc)
WHERE addrnumber = @<fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

MOVE-CORRESPONDING wa_adrc TO ls_adrc."Copy default address values
"modify address fields here
"ls_adrc-street
"ls_adrc-str_suppl1
"ls_adrc-str_suppl2
"ls_adrc-str_suppl3
"ls_adrc-city1
"ls_adrc-post_code1
"ls_adrc-region
"ls_adrc-country

" Generate temporary handle
CALL FUNCTION 'GUID_CREATE'
IMPORTING
ev_guid_32 = l_h32.
l_handle = l_h32+0(16).

SELECT SINGLE addr_group FROM adrc INTO l_ag
WHERE addrnumber = <fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

"Insert new address
CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_INSERT'
EXPORTING
address_data = ls_adrc
address_group = l_ag
address_handle = l_handle
IMPORTING
address_data = ls_adrc_new
returncode = l_ret
TABLES
error_table = lt_errtab
EXCEPTIONS
OTHERS = 1.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful New Address insert

SELECT SINGLE appl_table appl_field appl_key addr_group owner
FROM adrv
INTO (l_ref-appl_table,l_ref-appl_field,l_ref-appl_key,l_ref-addr_group,l_ref-owner)
WHERE addrnumber = <fs_vbpa>-adrnr.

CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_NUMBER_GET'
EXPORTING
address_handle = l_handle " Handle used in address creation
address_reference = l_ref " Optional: reference object
IMPORTING
address_number = l_nadrnr
EXCEPTIONS
address_handle_not_exist = 1
internal_error = 2
parameter_error = 3
OTHERS = 4.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful New Address number

CALL FUNCTION 'ADDR_MEMORY_SAVE'
EXPORTING
execute_in_update_task = ' '
EXCEPTIONS
address_number_missing = 1
person_number_missing = 2
internal_error = 3
database_error = 4
reference_missing = 5
OTHERS = 6.
IF sy-subrc = 0."Successful save of New Address number
<fs_vbpa>-adrnr = l_nadrnr.
ENDIF.

ENDIF."End of if Successful New Address number

ENDIF."End of if Successful New Address insert
ENDLOOP.

entry.title: The Ultimate SAP S/4HANA Guide for the Order-to-Cash Process
entry.content:
Introduction

Welcome to your end-to-end guide for navigating the sales process in SAP S/4HANA. Whether you're creating your first sales order, configuring the system, or testing a full business process, this document is for you. We will demystify core concepts, provide step-by-step instructions, and explain the "why" behind the "how."

Key Concepts in S/4HANA

  • SAP Fiori Launchpad: Your modern, role-based entry point to all applications. Instead of memorizing transaction codes, you'll use intuitive tiles to launch your tasks.
  • Business Role: Your Fiori Launchpad is tailored to your job. A Sales Representative sees different apps than a Warehouse Clerk or an Accounts Receivable Accountant.
  • Single Source of Truth: S/4HANA's in-memory database provides real-time insights. The data you see in sales is the same data seen in finance and logistics, instantly.

Chapter 1: The Foundation - Master Data

Before any transaction can occur, the system needs to know the "who," "what," and "how." This is the role of master data. It's the static data that is used repeatedly in your business transactions.

1.1. Business Partner (Customer)

In S/4HANA, the classic "Customer Master" is replaced by the Business Partner (BP). A single BP can have multiple roles, such as Customer, Supplier, or Contact Person.

How-To: Create a Customer

  1. App: Open the Manage Business Partner Master Data Fiori app.
  2. Click Create -> Organization.
  3. BP Role: Select FLCU00 - FI Customer to create the financial accounting data. Enter company code, reconciliation account, and payment terms.
  4. Click Save. The system will assign a BP number.
  5. Extend the BP: Re-open the BP you just created. Click Edit. In the "Create in Role" dropdown, select FLCU01 - Customer to add the sales-specific data.
  6. Go to the Sales and Distribution tab. Here you will enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, Division (the Sales Area), as well as key data like Shipping Conditions, Delivery Priority, and Billing information.
  7. Click Save.

1.2. Product (Material Master)

The Product Master (or Material Master) contains all information about a product or service that your company buys, produces, sells, or stores.

How-To: Create a Finished Product

  1. App: Use the Manage Product Master Data Fiori app.
  2. Click Create.
  3. Enter a Product Number (or leave blank for internal numbering), Product Type (e.g., FERT for Finished Good), and a Base Unit of Measure (e.g., EA for Each).
  4. Views: The Product Master is organized into views. For a sellable product, you'll need to create at least the following:
    • Basic Data: Description, unit of measure, dimensions.
    • Sales: The delivering plant, tax classifications, and sales unit.
    • MRP 1-4: Data for production planning, such as MRP Type (e.g., PD for MRP) and Availability Check group. This is crucial for determining product availability during a sales order.
    • General Plant Data / Storage: Storage conditions and handling information.
    • Accounting: Valuation Class (which drives G/L account determination) and the price (standard or moving average).
  5. Populate the required fields in each view and click Save.

1.3. Pricing Condition Records

This master data determines the price of a product for a customer. It's the foundation of your pricing strategy.

How-To: Set a Product Price

  1. App: Use the Manage Prices - Sales Fiori app.
  2. Select a Condition Type, such as PR00 for a basic price or K007 for a customer-specific discount.
  3. Enter the Sales Organization and Distribution Channel.
  4. In the table, enter the Product, the Amount (e.g., 100 EUR), and the Unit (e.g., 1 EA).
  5. Set the Validity Period for which this price is active.
  6. Click Save.

Chapter 2: The Sales Order - Heart of the Process

The sales order is the central document in the sales process. It's a contractual agreement between your company and a customer to deliver products or services. Here, we'll see how various configuration elements come together to control the document's behavior.

2.1. Creating a Sales Order

The primary Fiori app for this is a modern equivalent of the classic VA01 transaction.

How-To: Create a Standard Sales Order

  1. App: Open the Create Sales Orders Fiori app.
  2. Order Type: Enter the order type, for example, OR for a Standard Order.
  3. Organizational Data: Enter the Sales Organization, Distribution Channel, and Division.
  4. Header Data:
    • Enter the Sold-To Party (the customer number). The system will automatically populate related partners like the Ship-To Party.
    • Enter a Customer Reference number (their PO number).
  5. Item Data:
    • In the "Items" table, enter the Product number and the Order Quantity.
    • Press Enter. The system will perform a series of background actions: pricing, availability check, text determination, etc.
  6. Review the details, check the confirmed quantities and dates, and click Save.

2.2. Understanding the "Why": Order Reasons

Concept: An Order Reason is a code that explains why a customer placed an order. This is invaluable for sales analysis and reporting. Was it a result of a marketing campaign? A replacement for a damaged shipment? This information helps you understand your business drivers.

When you create a sales order, you can assign an order reason at the header level, which then applies to all items.

Examples of Standard Order Reasons:

  • 001: Poor quality
  • 002: Transport damage
  • 006: Machine trials
  • 008: Other

How-To: Assign an Order Reason

In the Create Sales Orders app, go to the Sales tab at the header level. You will find the Order Reason field. Use the dropdown to select the appropriate reason.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Order Reasons

You can define your own Order Reasons to match your business needs.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction OVAU
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Header -> Define Order Reasons

2.3. Controlling Line Items: Item Categories

Concept: The Item Category is one of the most powerful control elements in SD. It is automatically determined by the system based on the Sales Document Type and the material master, and it dictates the behavior of a line item in a sales document.

Key Questions the Item Category Answers:

  • Is this item relevant for pricing? (e.g., a standard item is, but a free-of-charge item is not).
  • Is this item relevant for delivery? (e.g., a standard product is, but a text item is not).
  • Is this item relevant for billing? (e.g., a standard item is, but a free sample might not be).
  • Does this item consume stock?
  • Should a schedule line be created for this item?

Common Standard Item Categories:

  • TAN: Standard Item. Relevant for pricing, delivery, and billing.
  • TANN: Free of Charge Item. Not relevant for pricing, but is relevant for delivery.
  • TATX: Text Item. Not relevant for pricing, delivery, or billing. Used for adding notes.
  • TAD: Service Item. Relevant for pricing and billing, but not for delivery as there is no physical product movement.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Item Categories

Item categories are highly configurable to support a wide variety of business scenarios.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction VOV7
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Item -> Define Item Categories
  • Assignment: The system determines the item category using an assignment table. You can view this in transaction VOV4. The path is ... -> Sales Document Item -> Assign Item Categories.

2.4. Ensuring Data Quality: Incompletion Procedures

Concept: An Incompletion Procedure acts as a data quality checklist for your sales documents. You can define critical fields that must be filled in before a document can proceed to the next step in the process. If a mandatory field is missing, the system flags the document as "incomplete" and can block subsequent functions like delivery or billing.

For example, you can configure the system to prevent delivery creation if the customer's PO number is missing from the sales order.

How it Works:

  1. Status Group: First, you define a Status Group which specifies what functions are blocked. For example, a status group might block "Delivery Creation" or "Billing Document Creation."
  2. Incompletion Procedure: Next, you create a procedure where you list the mandatory fields (e.g., table VBAK, field AUGRU for Order Reason).
  3. Assign Status Group: For each field in your procedure, you assign a Status Group. This tells the system what to block if that specific field is empty.
  4. Assign Procedure: Finally, you assign the entire incompletion procedure to a Sales Document Type (for header fields) or an Item Category (for item fields).

Example in Action:

A user creates a sales order but forgets to enter the Payment Terms (VBKD-ZTERM).

  • The Incompletion Procedure assigned to the sales order type contains this field.
  • The procedure is configured to block Billing if this field is empty.
  • When the user saves, a pop-up appears listing the missing data.
  • The user can save the incomplete document, but when someone later tries to create an invoice, the system will issue an error message stating the sales order is incomplete.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Incompletion

This is a multi-step configuration process that offers powerful control.

  1. Define Status Groups: SAP GUI OVA0. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Log of Incomplete Items -> Define Status Groups.
  2. Define Incompletion Procedures: SAP GUI OVA2. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Log of Incomplete Items -> Define Incompletion Procedures. Here you will add the tables, field names, and assign the status groups.
  3. Assign to Document Types/Item Categories: Path: ... -> Assign Incompletion Procedures to the Sales Document Types.

Note: The custom schemas Z1, Z2, ZG, ZN from the source documents would be implemented as new entries in these standard configuration tables.

2.5. Rejecting Unwanted Items: Rejection Reasons

Concept: A customer may decide not to proceed with a specific item in their order after it has been created. Instead of deleting the line, the best practice is to assign a Rejection Reason.

Why Reject instead of Delete?

  • Traceability: It maintains a record of what was originally requested and why it was cancelled.
  • Reporting: You can run reports to analyze why items are being rejected (e.g., "Too Expensive," "Long Delivery Time"). This provides valuable feedback to your sales, product, and logistics teams.
  • System Impact: Assigning a rejection reason automatically nullifies the item. It is no longer considered in MRP (demand planning) and cannot be delivered or billed.

Common Rejection Reasons:

  • 01: Delivery date too long
  • 02: Poor quality
  • 03: Too expensive
  • 04: Competitor has better service

How-To: Reject a Line Item

  1. In the Change Sales Orders (VA02) app, navigate to the line item you wish to reject.
  2. Go to the Reason for Rejection tab.
  3. Select an appropriate reason from the dropdown list.
  4. Click Save. The item will be updated and will no longer be active.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Rejection Reasons

You can create reasons that are specific to your industry or business.

  • SAP GUI: Transaction OVAG
  • SPRO/CBC Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Sales Document Item -> Define Reasons For Rejection

Chapter 3: Availability Check and Delivery Scheduling

Once a sales order is entered, the system must answer two critical questions:

  1. Can we fulfill this order? (Availability Check)
  2. When can the customer expect it? (Delivery Scheduling)

3.1. The Availability Check (ATP)

Concept: The Available-to-Promise (ATP) check is a real-time process that determines if the requested material will be available on the requested date. It doesn't just look at current stock; it's a dynamic calculation that considers:

  • Current unrestricted stock
  • Inbound movements (e.g., planned production orders, purchase orders)
  • Outbound movements (e.g., other sales orders, reservations)

The rules governing this check are defined by the Checking Group in the material master and the Checking Rule from the SD transaction (e.g., 'A' for sales order). Together, they determine the scope of the check.

S/4HANA introduces Advanced ATP (aATP), which offers more sophisticated features like real-time, multi-level checks and intelligent backorder processing.

Backorder Processing: When new stock arrives, a backorder processing run can automatically re-evaluate open sales orders and re-confirm them against the new inventory, potentially improving delivery dates for high-priority customers.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing ATP

Configuring the ATP check is a cross-functional effort involving SD and MM/PP consultants.

  • Define Checking Groups: SPRO -> ... -> Basic Functions -> Availability Check and Transfer of Requirements -> Availability Check -> Availability Check with ATP Logic or Against Planning -> Define Checking Groups.
  • Define Checking Rule for Backorders: SAP GUI OMIH. Path: ... -> Determine Rule for Control of Backorder Processing. This is where you assign a checking rule per plant for backorder processing runs.

3.2. Delivery Scheduling

Concept: Delivery Scheduling calculates the actual dates for the entire shipping process. The system performs backward scheduling from the customer's requested delivery date to determine if it's feasible.

It calculates the following key dates:

  1. Goods Issue Date: The day the goods must leave the plant.
  2. Loading Date: When loading must begin.
  3. Material Availability Date: The latest date the material must be available for picking and packing to start.
  4. Transportation Planning Date: When transportation planning must begin.

This calculation depends on several factors:

  • Transit Time: Time from your plant to the customer (from the Route).
  • Loading Time: Time to load the truck (from the Shipping Point).
  • Pick/Pack Time: Time to gather and pack the goods (from the Shipping Point).

Scheduling Control:

  • By Sales Document Type: You can switch scheduling on or off for an entire document type. For example, you would enable it for a standard order (OR) but disable it for a contract (CQ), as a contract doesn't trigger an immediate delivery.
  • By Shipping Point: Each shipping point can have its own working hours (via a Factory Calendar) and default times for picking, packing, and loading, making the calculation highly specific to the fulfillment location.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Scheduling

  • Activate for Sales Doc Type: SAP GUI OVLY. Path: ... -> Basic Functions -> Delivery Scheduling and Transportation Scheduling -> Define Scheduling By Sales Document Type.
  • Define for Shipping Point: SAP GUI OVLZ. Path: ... -> Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Basic Shipping Functions -> Scheduling -> Delivery Scheduling and Transportation Scheduling -> Define Scheduling By Shipping Point.

3.3. Controlling Procurement and Delivery: Schedule Line Categories

Concept: If the Item Category controls the what of a line item, the Schedule Line Category controls the when and how of its fulfillment. For each item in a sales order, there can be one or more schedule lines, each with a date and a confirmed quantity.

The Schedule Line Category determines:

  • Is this schedule line relevant for delivery?
  • Does it generate a transfer of requirements to planning (MRP)?
  • Does it trigger a specific inventory movement type (e.g., 601 for goods issue for a delivery)?
  • Can it be part of an availability check?

Common Standard Schedule Line Categories:

  • CP: Standard. Relevant for MRP and delivery.
  • CN: No MRP, no delivery. Used for items that are not planned or shipped (like services).
  • DN: Returns. Used in return orders to manage the inbound goods movement.
  • CB: Individual Purchase Order. This schedule line will automatically trigger the creation of a purchase requisition to procure the goods specifically for this sales order.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Schedule Line Categories

  • Define Schedule Line Categories: SAP GUI VOV6. Path: Sales and Distribution -> Sales -> Sales Documents -> Schedule Lines -> Define Schedule Line Categories.
  • Assignment: The system determines the schedule line category based on the Item Category and the MRP type from the material master. This is configured in SAP GUI VOV5. Path: ... -> Schedule Lines -> Assign Schedule Line Categories.

Chapter 4: Logistics and Fulfillment (LE, EWM, TM)

With a confirmed sales order in hand, the process moves from Sales to Logistics. The goal is to physically pick, pack, and ship the goods to the customer.

4.1. Creating the Outbound Delivery

The outbound delivery document is the starting point for all shipping activities. It contains all the data needed for picking, packing, goods issue, and transportation planning.

How-To: Create an Outbound Delivery

  1. App: Use the Create Outbound Deliveries from Sales Orders Fiori app. This app provides a worklist of sales orders due for shipment.
  2. Enter your Shipping Point and the selection dates.
  3. The system displays a list of open sales order items ready for delivery.
  4. Select the items you want to deliver and click Create Deliveries.
  5. The system creates the outbound delivery document(s).

4.2. Applying Brakes: Delivery Blocks

Based on source document: Définir motif blocage liv.doc

Concept: A Delivery Block is a mechanism to temporarily halt the shipping process for a specific order or even a single schedule line. The block can be set manually by a user or automatically by the system.

Common Reasons for a Delivery Block:

  • 01: For commercial approval
  • 02: Credit limit exceeded (often set automatically)
  • 03: Price not available
  • 06: Political reasons

A delivery block prevents the creation of an outbound delivery document. The block must be removed in the sales order before the logistics process can continue.

How it's Used:

  • Header Level: Set in the sales order header (in the Billing Document tab), it blocks the entire order.
  • Schedule Line Level: A block can also be set for a specific schedule line, allowing other parts of the order to be delivered. This is useful if one item is on hold but others are cleared for shipment.

Consultant's Corner: Customizing Delivery Blocks

  • Define Delivery Blocks: SAP GUI OVLS. Path: Logistics Execution -> Shipping -> Deliveries -> Define Reasons for Blocking in Shipping.
  • Here you can define the block reasons and specify their impact. For example, you can have a block that stops delivery creation but still allows requirements to be passed to MRP.

4.3. Warehouse and Transportation Processing (EWM & TM)

Once the outbound delivery is created, it flows into the warehouse and transportation systems.

  • Extended Warehouse Management (EWM):
    1. The outbound delivery triggers the creation of a Warehouse Request in EWM.
    2. This leads to the creation of Warehouse Tasks (e.g., picking tasks).
    3. A warehouse operator, often using an RF scanner, executes the tasks: picking the goods from a storage bin.
    4. The goods are brought to a packing station where they are packed into Handling Units (HUs), like boxes or pallets.
    5. The packed goods are moved to the goods issue area.
  • Transportation Management (TM):
    1. The outbound delivery creates a Freight Unit in TM.
    2. The planner combines freight units into a Freight Order.
    3. The planner performs carrier selection and tenders the freight order to a shipping company.

4.4. Post Goods Issue (PGI)

This is the final step in the shipping process. Posting the goods issue legally transfers ownership of the goods and has significant financial implications.

Key Impacts of PGI:

  • Inventory Reduction: The stock of the material is reduced in inventory management (MM).
  • Financial Posting: A financial journal entry is created automatically:
    • Credit (-) Inventory Account
    • Debit (+) Cost of Goods Sold (COGS) Account
  • Delivery Status Update: The status of the outbound delivery is updated to "Completed."
  • Billing Due List: The delivery document is now ready for invoicing and will appear on the billing due list.

How-To: Post Goods Issue

PGI can be done from several Fiori apps, including Manage Outbound Deliveries or directly by the EWM system upon confirmation of loading.

Chapter 5: Billing and Financial Integration

The final step in the O2C process is to invoice the customer and receive payment.

5.1. Creating the Customer Invoice

The billing document is created by referencing the outbound delivery (for goods) or the sales order (for services).

How-To: Create an Invoice

  1. App: Use the Create Billing Documents Fiori app.
  2. The app presents a worklist of documents due for billing (the Billing Due List).
  3. Select the deliveries or sales orders you want to invoice.
  4. The system creates the billing documents. You can review them before saving.
  5. Upon saving, the invoice is created.

5.2. The Financial Impact

Saving the billing document triggers another automatic, real-time integration with Finance:

  • Debit (+) Customer Accounts Receivable (AR) sub-ledger. This means the customer now owes you money.
  • Credit (-) Sales Revenue Account.
  • Credit (-) Tax Payable Account.

A corresponding journal entry is posted automatically in the Universal Journal.

5.3. Receiving Customer Payment

The final step is processing the incoming payment from the customer, which clears the open receivable on their account. This is typically handled by the Accounts Receivable department using Fiori apps like Post Incoming Payments.

Test Scenario 3: ATP and Backorder Scenario

Objective: To test the system's behavior when there is insufficient stock and how it handles new inventory.

Step

Test Step Description

Action to Perform (Fiori App)

Input Data

Expected Result

3.1

Create Order with Stock Shortage

Create Sales Orders

Prerequisite: Ensure available stock for PROD-STD-01 is only 5 EA. Order PROD-STD-01 with a quantity of 15.

The system should create two schedule lines for the item: Line 1 with a confirmed quantity of 5 for today's date. Line 2 with a confirmed quantity of 0 (or 10 for a future date, depending on ATP config).

3.2

Post Goods Receipt for Purchasing Document (or other GR app)

The available stock for the product is now 25 EA.

3.3

Schedule BOP Run

Create and schedule a run for the relevant material/plant combination.

The BOP run should identify the open sales order from step 3.1. It should re-evaluate the availability and update the order, creating a single schedule line with a confirmed quantity of 15 for today's date.

3.4

Create Outbound Deliveries

 

You should now be able to create a delivery for the full quantity of 15 EA.
